awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Reconfigurability and Technology Integration  of Magnetic Energy Minimization Co-Processor (MEMCoP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative proposal been two universities - USF and UCLA - advocates a new form of computing that uses circular nanomagnets to solve quadratic optimization problems, orders of magnitude faster than that of a conventional computer. A wide range of application domains can be potentially accelerated through this research, e.g., computationally expensive and hard to parallelize problems of finding patterns in social media, error-correcting codes, big data applications etc. The project plans to engage undergraduate REU students, and the PIs will be involved with the local community through interaction with K-12 teachers and K7-K8 women students. As a part of Sloan University Center for Exemplary Mentoring (UCEM), the lead PI will recruit and retain undergraduate students. The UCLA team will work with a group of undergraduate students sponsored by Center for Excellence in Engineering and Diversity (CEED).

Core computational theme of this proposal is mapping quadratic energy minimization problem spaces into a set of interacting magnets such that the energy relationship between the problem variables is proportional to that of the energies between the corresponding magnets. The optimization is accomplished by the relaxation physics of the magnets themselves and solutions can be read-out in parallel. In essence, given a specific instance of the problem, the plan is to arrive at a specific magnetic layout, the relaxed state of which will be the solution of the original problem.  Reconfigurability is fundamental to the success of this form of high-payoff computing (one does not intend to fabricate a specific magnetic layout to solve one instance of a problem). Three alternative programming solutions are proposed, and trade-offs between the mechanisms will be evaluated. The project also plans to explore reconfigurability together with readability and system integration aspects.

por.por_cntn:
This project explores Physics-inspired computing to achieve futuristic HPC systems and harnesses the innate physical properties of nanomagnets to directly solve computationally hard problems in one-shot fashion. A proof-of-concept of this research direction was published in Nature Nanotechnology that solves a quadratic Computer vision optimization problem. We call this co-processor the “Magnetic Energy Minimization Co-Processor (MEMCoP),” which can be integrated with CMOS for peripheral as well as other general computing needs.

Core computational theme of this proposal is mapping quadratic energy minimization problem spaces into a set of interacting magnets such that the energy relationship between the problem variables is proportional to that of the energies between the corresponding magnets. The optimization is actually accomplished by the relaxation physics of the magnets themselves and solutions can be read-out in parallel. In essence, given a specific instance of the problem, we will arrive at a specific magnetic layout, the relaxed state, of which will be the solution of the original problem.

Goal of this proposal is to explore material, device, and I/O interface to achieve reconfigurability, readability, and seamless integration with conventional technology. The significance of reconfigurability is that, without it, a separate layout of nanomagnets must be fabricated for every single problem to be solved. Reading the magnetic cells is a crucial component and is coupled with design choices created for reconfiguration.

We are happy to report two effective measures of programmability. The first method was to utilize spin-orbital torque to induce programmability. SOT current was applied to impact magnetization of the center disk in a five disk arrangement with varying current slopes while the adjacent disks were clocked to the z-direction. The results of this study revealed that, by applying SOT current with very high ramp slope, the ground states of adjacent disks could be switched from single domain in-plane states to vortex states. Thus the center disk was programmable by SOT. Moreover, the current required to achieve programmability using high ramp-slope can be significantly lower than the previously determined critical switching current with lower slope. In the context of non-Boolean computational platforms, such as the MEMCoP co-processor, this result demonstrates the capability to selectively program a 2D dipole-coupled array of nanodisks. High-slope ramp current also imply faster programmability. The second method of programmability is through spin-transfer-toque (STT). We are able to effectively program a cell in a grid of magnetic cells into a non-computing state such that its magnetic influence is nullified as far as the magnetic system is concerned. Thus, any magnetic layout can be created by selectively programming cells into non-computing states. Moreover, STT mechanism has an advantage in hardware integration because they can mirror the integration of STT-MRAM memories, which is supported by most of the state-of-the-art foundries.

Reading the magnetic cells was initially an issue as these circular magnets are difficult to read compared to STT-MRAM memories.  We have proposed various reading schemes to evaluate energy, and delay tradeoffs. Most importantly, we have designed a pre-amplifier stage to boost reliability of reading, which is the most effective way to read the magnets without a significant tradeoff in energy and delay.

Extending our knowledge of sensing nanomagnets, we have experimented with Domain-wall memory (DWM). DWMs are used by various Neuromorphic Architecture research paradigms.  In collaboration with faculty and students of University of Pittsburgh, we formulated a transverse read mechanism which helps in position faults in DWM. For domain-wall memories to become viable, the shifting reliability must be addressed. We focused on addressing position faults, i.e., faults that cause the entire racetrack to over-shift or under-shift by one or several domains. Our knowledge of sensing magnetic states has helped us propose a novel transverse reading mechanism (TR), where we exploit the physics of current-driven domain-wall motion. The transverse read reports the number of ones stored between two points along the nanowire, starting and ending at an access port or an end of the nanowire. To verify the efficacy of our technique, we applied TR in domain-wall nanowires with both in-plane and perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (IMA/PMA), respectively. We also demonstrate how TR can be applied to partial segments of the nanowire, such as from an end to an access point or between access points. Utilizing this approach, we have worked on Transverse error correcting codes (TECC), which creates a signature from information constructed by accessing data along the nanowire.

Hence, we have achieved the goals and objectives of achieving a programmable and readable magnetic co-processor that can solve hard optimization problems harnessing the systemic behaviors of nano-magnets. Ongoing effort will focus on a larger class of alternate neuromorphic computing network that relies on real-time learning. We will harness properties of magnetic systems to create programmable synapses which will help in achieving end-to-end neuromorphic magnetic edge computing framework.
